author: chrissorem
content: This made me think of a production technique Ive stumbled on.  We all have our go to instincts that can lead to a similar feeling across a  record.  Generally there is a dominant instrument that the song was written on such as guitar or piano maybe a synth.  Take a filled out productions and mute all the main ingredients and leave the additive colors, only the sprinkles on top. And start rebuilding the production around that. It can take you to an entirely different  universe and provide contrast in the arch of the record

author: ALXCPH
content:
Peeps making Reese bases themselves in serum. 

When you’ve made the sound how you want you’ll often find with stereo Reese bases the fundamental is phasing in and out so your low end isn’t very consistent. 

What you can do is go into the waveform editor on the oscillators and click “remove fundamental” then enable the separate sub Osc and set it to direct out. That way you get a nice consistent fundamental, but your harmonics are still moving giving you that classic Reese sound but with a much beefier stable low end. 

Hit my DM if anyone needs me to be more specific 😇

author: Zack Hames
content:
You’re gonna hate this. But the best way is to just get more reps to get faster and better. 10,000 hours, no shortcuts.

But more actionable advice - stick to a slim number of EQ and Compressor plugs and just use those. For example 99% of my mixes just use pro q3, API-2500, and Kush AR-1. The idea being minimize variables and decisions, and use stuff you know ridiculously well.

Production side, I find having go to sounds, samples, and instruments (hardware or software) well learned and ready to go shortens the path from opening your project to creating music. For me, this is taking my free time to mess with my MPC and explore samples, or to create patches on my synths to become more intertwined with my instruments. This is separate from the actual “I’m gonna make a song today” process.

Ultimately…make a song in 8 hours as many days as you can. If you TRY every day, that’s better than nothing. By the end of a month, even if you only made FOUR tracks…that’s better than nothing and it just adds up.

author: LAPhill
content:
By far, the most important element in realistic orchestral sound is in the programming. You need a controller where you can automate cc1 and cc11 (modulation and expression). Instruments, especially strings, are constantly changing their volumes. Particularly on entrances and phrase-ends. If you don't have a controller for this, you can draw it all in, but that gets really tedious.

If you get that figured out, I can almost guarantee that just about any library out there will get you good results. So then it's just a matter of what sound do you gravitate towards, how elaborate of a feature set do you need, etc. Legatos are overrated and I'd take no legato over a poorly programmed one any day.

If you want a full orchestra, not just strings, I'd check out some of the all-in-one offerings from Spitfire (Albion, BBC Orchestra, or Abbey Road), East West, Orchestral Tools (Inspire), or VSL (Prime). They all will have several different articulations, a decent amount of dynamic layers, and a full set of orchestral instruments. Have a listen to them and see what sounds grab you. Spitfire and Orchestral Tools have a more prominent room sound baked in, but they all do to some extent. So be aware that, whichever library you choose, there's a certain amount of "reverb" (which is actually just the hall they're recorded in) that you will never be able to turn off.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I think these things are cumulative… so…
Vintech was able to sell a ton of units because on the NAMM floor their pre was indistinguishable from a 1073 costing 4 times as much. But, if you took one home and used it as your one pre across 100 tracks of your masterpiece, even your parents are going to hear the difference between it and a vintage neve. That small 5% difference really added up at the end. I’m sure after floor two of the leaning tower of Pisa the engineers we’re like “lookin good boss! 👍🏼 “ and it wasn’t til they compounded their error that people started to panic.
If you’re making tracks 95% in the box with samples and soft synths and then just drop a featured rapper on top of it, it’s probably not going to matter if you use a Scarlett or an Apollo or an Apogee. But if you’re a professional mixer constantly printing stuff 100x a session through outboard gear you’re going to notice a difference I can guarantee you. Or if you’re doing a Low record where there’s only three elements and one of them is the most gifted voice of a generation, the gear is going to matter a lot more than if you’re squeezing a TikTok star into 37 plugins and then into a 150 track mix.

So at the end of the day, much like producing, songwriting or pretty much everything else in life, it’s that old prayer of strength to change the things you can, the grace to accept the things you can’t, and the most important bit that everyone seems to skip over, THE WISDOM TO KNOW THE DIFFERENCE. 

Do what works for you, and clearly, I sweat the details enough to notice that the algorithms are different, or Cians dangerous was down a half a db on one side, but also, when to actually use that information to actually make the actual point. Otherwise you end up being a photographer that does nothing but collect backs and lenses but never actually takes a photo.

author: wilhelmjosephk
content: One thing I love to do to help me wrap my head around sounds and tools is basically “transcribing” a preset to a new initialized patch on the same synth. Keep hitting the keys as you go to see how copying each setting changes the sound, and see if the end result is the same when you think you’re done. Often you’ll be completely missing some modulator somewhere and you’ll really need to dig through the synth’s features to find something you didn’t know before. As a bonus, you can try the same thing but have the synth that the preset comes from and the synth you’re recreating it in be two different tools, like trying to remake you’re favorite serum patch in Pigments. Sometimes certain features will be missing outright and you’ll just have to use your ears to get close, but I find this really useful for figuring the inherent differences in the tools at my disposal. Best thing about both of these exercises is they only take about 10-15 minutes a patch, then you’re on to something new

author: Slow Hand
content:
Wow. I'm making my way slowly through this Lanois/Beato interview and am amazed by what Lanois is describing from @ 52:24 to 53:45 regarding his approach to stacking modulations and special effects.

As he describes it, he's performing and printing his modulation effects (delay, verb, vibrato, pitch shifting, etc) one generation at a time as he iterates through the song. This allows him to fine-tune and perform the modulations on each successive pass so that every moment is honed and responsive enough that it becomes a part within the music, and not just a blanket effects chain.

So if he's doing pitch-shifted delays, he'll do a pass that goes up a fifth on certain notes and then layer another pass that modulates by a different interval at a select moment instead of leaving everything on throughout the entire section. He's honing each effect in sequence. It shows a tremendous care and sensitivity to the music that he would go through and *perform* each layer with so much intention.

This feels like a revelation to me and I can't wait to practice this.

(I've cued up the video where they start talking about it)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vxP9kKzbCFA&t=3144s

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yes. *Supermassive* gets regular usage over here. Sean should charge for that plugin because it's so good.

It's a delay plugin that specializes in super-long and evolving echoes with lots of modulation. Sean has described the different algorithms as "too exotic" for his other plugins so he bundled them all together as *Supermassive*.

It certainly excels in that role, and also doubles as a good lush reverb when you turn up the diffusion knob.

Funnily, I almost never use it for long echoes. As it turns out, it's really good at creating super-tight and roomy sounds. Just dial the delay time to < 15 ms and turn up the feedback and suddenly you have a very lush and chorus-y "room" sound. Kind of like a Quantec or something from a Jimmy Edgar record.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Good question! 

As @cian riordan said, when you're perfectly lining up the waveform of any solid tone, you want equal gain so it doesn't give you a boost on the crossfade. This is for "correlated" signals where the waveform is lining up exactly. A bass guitar, the middle of a vocal note, a synth with a consistent waveform, etc.

When you're doing a crossfade on noise (breaths, sss's, ambience between drum hits, etc), you want equal power because these "uncorrelated" signals need a bit of boost around the crossfade for the perceived loudness to be the same.

You can check this by using a synth note or long vocal note, doing an edit to make it longer or shorter, lining up the waveforms perfectly, and doing a cross fade. You will find that equal power causes a volume bump. Equal gain will be smooth.

Do the same thing with white noise and this time equal power will be smooth, while equal gain will cause a volume dip.

author: austenballard
content:
Test is done. Tl;dr they don't null completely. They don't even detect the same audio the same.

**INTRODUCTION**
Beckley, et al. (2023) reported differences in tuning results between the plugin and standalone versions of Melodyne. This investigator undertook a test of Melodyne plugin, ARA and standalone versions to determine whether the resulting tuned audio would null.

**METHODS**

All testing was performed at a sample rate of 48kHz and with .wav files at a bit depth of 32 bits. Tuning was tested using two 2-second square wave tones generated with FabFilter One in Logic Pro X. Tone #1 was generated at a constant pitch of C4 +50ct. Tone #2 was generated at a pitch of C4 with the following settings: Modulation Generator (MG) Frequency set to 4.033 Hz,  MG waveform set to value 0.500, and Frequency Modulation MG set to value 0.123. Each tone was printed on a separate channel as a Bounce-in-place (bip). The two bips were then joined into a single, 6-second, mono .wav file with 2 seconds of silence between the bips. The 6-second .wav file was copied onto two new channels in Logic Pro X, and dragged out of Logic Pro onto the desktop for use in Melodyne standalone.

Audio was transferred into Melodyne: one mono channel in Logic Pro X was loaded with an instance of Melodyne non-ARA, one mono channel in Logic Pro X was loaded with an instance of Melodyne ARA, and the copy of the .wav file on the desktop was loaded into Melodyne standalone. All transfers were completed using the Melodic (Standard) algorithm. 

Transferred audio was quantized to pitch C4, offset 0 ct, Pitch Modulation 0.0%, Pitch Drift 0.0%. All other settings were left at defaults; Note Assignment mode was checked to verify that Playback Type in each case was 'Tonal'. 

Resulting audio was printed and imported into three new mono channels in Logic Pro X. Null testing was performed using the phase invert feature in Logic Pro X's stock 'Gain' plugin.

author: Slow Hand
content:
One tip I'd give is to make your patch while you have a MIDI sequence playing. Not just some static, even arpeggio that you drew in, but a part that has different articulations, note lengths, velocities, and covers a range of notes.

It's easy when making a patch to just keep your finger on one key and go *doot doot doot* (tweak) *doot doot doot* (tweak again). What you can end up doing this way is optimizing the patch and parameters for a single note or handful of notes. And it gets old to listen to. By keeping the entire musical part playing you're going to move through building a well-balanced patch much quicker.

If you have a part in mind, record the MIDI with your starter/init patch, spend some time tweaking the patch while the sequence plays, and then once you get into the ballpark replay the MIDI part using your new patch. The new synth settings will influence your articulation and feel when you record the second time around. Then refine your patch as needed. Rinse and repeat until you're satisfied.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Three things come to mind: 

1) **Note length and envelope**. That's going to have a large influence on the feel. Electronic producers will spend a *lot* of time sculpting the volume envelope relative to the tempo. Trance producers have entire plugins that give them microscopic control over the pitch and volume envelopes of kick drums.

2) **Presentation and proportion**. Is it up-front or does it sink into the back? It's easy for a 4x4 to feel hackneyed or overbearing. Sometimes all you need is a gentle *pat pat pat pat* to tie things together.

A fresh or unconventional texture will open up drastically different feels. People can dance to anything if it's got a 4x4 click, so it doesn't necessarily *need* to be a kick. You can go far using samples and percussion that sit in different registers, but play the same role.

3) **Complimentary instruments**. If the kick is the "rock" then the groove is going to come from how everything else swings over that. What's the friction like between the kick and the other elements? If the kick is a "straight man", then the other elements pushing off of it are where the magic comes from.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Any polyphonic subtractive synth should be able to get you there. There's nothing so unique about the sound that you'd need a specific synth model. The characteristic sound of this patch is a saturated LPF with an ADSR filter sweep. It may actually be a monophonic synth with a second oscillator tuned to +7 and blended in at a lower volume. It doesn't sound like they're playing chords, so much as stacked oscillators.

As others mentioned, a Prophet is a good place to start, but it's not going to get you that heavy-grit saturation by itself that we hear on this record. Prophets don't get that dirty on their own. Maybe the Prophet X's with DSP effects will. I haven't used them.

Something like a Moog synth is going to lean heavier into the saturation capabilities. That record feels much more like a Moog filter. A Moog Matriarch is the first thing I'd reach for if it were available to use.

That said, you've probably got enough saturation boxes lying around that you can approximate that grit. But it's a very Moog-y saturation sound.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Easy! FM synthesis is simply vibrato that is super fast (greater than 20 Hz) - and often super deep (a semitone of pitch fluctuation or octaves of it). 

When you modulate the pitch at these rates and depths the vibrato is perceived as new harmonic sidebands that "bloom" out of the oscillator.

Great video.

author: Slow Hand
content:
If you know your way around a synthesizer, Massive X and Serum 2 are both heavy hitters that cover all of my bases. 

Sonically, Massive X has a "warmer" voicing and has all of NI's amazing effect algorithms built into it. Everything sounds incredible and is dripping with character. It's absurdly capable, but the interface may be overwhelming at first. It can be a lot to get oriented on. It's impossible for this thing to sound "cold". The preset library is less bass music/EDM and more balanced. NI offers a lot of genre-themed expansions. If you like programming sequenced/heavily automated one-button patches Massive X is king.

Serum is on the "cold" side, but just as capable of "warmer" sounds. The sonics and DSP are clear as a bell. Stellar. It's more intuitive to program and the feature set is an embarrassment of riches. It's absurd how much functionality Steve and team crammed into it. Absolutely absurd. If you want to do EDM and bass music, it's the king and it's preset library leans towards that. I still cannot believe that they *gave* it away to Serum 1 users.

Both excel at cinematic and over the top. If you're looking for the "classic" sound, I'd lean Massive X.

author: Deleted User
content:
usually saw/buzz basses can’t have much perceived subs without filtering because of the amount of upper harmonics. with shorter saw bass- I usually tend to favor the upper area for punch and get the low subs from kick and if I need lengths in the lows I double it with a sub or electric bass and not use the sub from the saw bass. on saw bass with longer sustain- I like to do band pass filtering (take out subs and filter out the sizzlely highs) and use a separate sub bass in the middle and use saw bass that spreads out on the sides. 

I wouldn’t do significant boost lows on saw bass, I find it just messes with the character of the sound too much

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yup! Massive was my go-to for years prior to Massive X.

The biggest change for me is that the raw oscillators sound far better. The original Massive had a lot of aliasing that could make it sound hazy and flat. Switching over to Massive X it is crystal clear and even buzzy saw waves feel warm, pure, and tactile.

It has extremely flexible modulation capabilities that I find to be very musical as well as some very comprehensive ADSHR envelopes. It also has four different keyboard tracking curves that you can assign and tweak, which is very important when fine-tuning your patch to make sure that it sounds even across the entire range of keys.

It has a lot of musical sounding filters that can inject a ton of vibe, or be completely neutral. The *noise* section is robust and very flexible. I use it a lot.

Finally, it has a great-sounding set of internal effects (delay, chorus, saturation, verb, etc) that can be placed anywhere inside of the routing diagram. It's always a bummer when the on-board effects aren't very inspiring. But NI has a strong catalog of well-designed dsp to draw on and integrate into their products, so it's turned out great.

Overall, it's a very robust and well-rounded synthesizer that also does a lot of things extremely well. It can be super clean (like Serum) but also get very dirty, which I appreciate in a synth.

The only thing I don't like is that the preset browser kind of sucks. I prefer the original Massive's browser. NI is well aware and they have been overhauling it and slowly adding new features, so I trust in time this will be made better.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I think the best thing you can do when learning a synthesizer is to pick just one or two and really take the time to learn them inside and out. There's so much overlap between the feature set and if you can get very intuitive with one synth you'll go so much farther.

Back in the day I bought NI's *Komplete* bundle and it was just way too many new instruments too fast. Too many options. I never got to know any of them very well. Most synths have all of the same features that you'll want, but there's still a learning curve for every single one that you have to get over before you can be really expressive. I wish it were as easy as picking up a guitar or a horn where everything is standardized and lies in the same place. But that's part of what makes synths great: Their plasticity.

Nowadays the only synths I reach for (unless I need a very specific sound) are *Massive X*, *Razor*, and my Moog Sub 37. The first two are very different and don't share many features. I use the Moog when I don't want to be tethered to my computer. Limiting my available tools has been a net benefit for me.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Lemme try again. 😄 I think you’d get very close with a Moog Matriarch or a Sub37. Turn the LPF filter down low and then use an ADSR envelope to modulate the filter cutoff frequency so that it sweeps open and closed every time you press a key.

Crank up the saturation knob on the Moog LPF and then blend in a second oscillator that’s tuned to a 5th above the pitch of your 1st oscillator.

author: Deleted User
content:
Polyphonic subtractive synth : subtractive synth is a synthesis mechanism that utilizes combination of oscillators and filters. So a synth with Osc, Filter  that can play more than one note at a time

ADSR filter sweep - ADSR is a type of enveloping shape. Attack time, Decay time, Sustain level, and Release time. Sweep here refers to when you make the envelope move the filter corner (cutoff) frequency. It acts like as if you are moving the filter by hand every time a key is triggered. 

Stacked Oscillators : When you have OSC1 and OSC2 tuned differently. In this case Bradley is referring to OSC2 being 7 semitones higher and having it on lower volume relative to OSC1.

author: Deleted User
content:
Learn what different carrier to modulator ratios sound like by messing with them only using sine waves.  and then feel out what it feels like feedback carrier and/or the modulator. And then you can introduce envelopes to create shapes with them. 

Tool wise- I would start with FM8, it’s pretty much DX7 but without the limitations of routing configuration like it does in Arturia DX7. And then you can learn with arturia DX7 in conjunction with how the different configuration work. +FM8 has patch morphing function which can be VERY useful when it comes to FM sounds. Another cool thing about FM8 is that it shows you all of the sidebands. 

From here, it’s all experimentation

That’s really all you need, FM looks intimidating but it’s really not that difficult. 


linear FM is essentially really fast vibrato. Non linear FM is a fast trill between the two frequencies. AM is essentially fast *unipolar* tremolo, RM is fast *bipolar: meaning it shifts polarity too* tremolo. they all create sonic characters by creating sidebands. 

one thing to keep in mind is most FM synths are actually not FM. it’s actually imitated by doing phase modulation- but results are almost identical. except in actual FM, you get more of the carrier frequency. So FM with a high-pass filtered modulator is essentially the same as PM with a low pass filtered modulator


run down on difference in sidebands between the most common audio-rate modulated synthesis:

FM/PM creates equally spaced sidebands

RM only produces sidebands (carrier frequency + modulator frequency & carrier frequency- modulator frequency)

AM is carrier with side bands of c+m and c-m

author: Slow Hand
content:
*Massive X* came out a few years ago and immediately became my main workhorse/swiss army synth.

It's extremely well rounded, deep, flexible, sounds *impeccable*, and has a wealth of well curated NI effects built in that make it a one-stop shop.

It's probably overkill for most people and I'm nowhere near close to squeezing all of the juice that it has to offer. But it's so comprehensive that I immediately stopped using 80% of my synths. At this point the only other synth I use is NI *Razor*, which is it's own distinct animal.

I could spend the rest of my life learning to master *Massive X*, and I feel confident that it's a worthy pursuit. It's allowed me to focus on mastering a single instrument. I've stopped being 20% good at several synths and am now deeply familiar with a single tool. I'm very pleased with it.

If it’s a matter of filling space, something that helped me on a pop track the other day was making a second track for echoes of the lead vocal where you can low pass it pretty hard and delay / verb it out.

I often find myself introducing subtle sub basses later in the song, potentially doubling electric bass with synth bass, maybe layering snares to be fatter in later choruses. Then playing with some subtle percussion elements like triangle, clave, wood blocks, to differentiate later choruses.

author: ALXCPH
content:
(It’s all super project dependant) If I’m both producing and tracking I’ll often just get the production to a point where it’s good to write to and simple enough to have ideas flow. Then throw it into a vocal tracking session and get the demo vocals and get the song written and record a few too many parts. Then produce the song around the song and vocals. Usually I’ll have beat and vocals separate, but sometimes it makes more sense to have in the same session. Depends on the song. But I always track over a 2 track. Because it takes a lot of risk out of having some random synth or plug-in chain from the production mess up the session while trying to get good takes with the artist.(total buzzkill if you have to restart a session when the vocalist is in the zone) 
But again soooooo project dependant. Depends on how the artist likes to work, time line, amount of sessions that are possible to have together and so on. author: Slow Hand
content:
Oh, just one more thing. I find it very helpful to practice making patches by trying to emulate a given instrument's expression. I'm primarily thinking about note articulation, here. Modeling these behaviors is a good way to start thinking musically with a synthesizer.

So if I'm going for a "horn" instrument I want a patch that can do attack-y stabs, but also fade into notes and have complete dynamic control. It should also have some sort of brightness feature that I can open up at will, like blowing harder into some brass.

If I'm emulating a voice there's going to be a big emphasis on legato playing and fluidity, with some very expressive pitch control for bends and vibrato. Maybe some form of subtle formant control to shade the notes like a singer would with different vowel sounds.

An organ patch is going to be a dead simple note-on/note-off volume envelope with the expression coming from the addition or subtraction of different oscillators.

And some patches are just going to be gangly chaotic messes that you do your best to wrangle. Something with a lot of chaos and feedback and squealing. You can't control it, but you just strap in.

author: Slow Hand
content: Yup. I'd have to test it to see how the technique compares sound-wise, but you can def do what Au5 has done in *Massive X* by assigning some of it's *Random LFO*s.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yup. It just depends on what synthesis techniques you take to. I def wouldn't use *Massive X* for anything but simple FM matrices. And I use *Razor* because it does additive in a very musical way.

That said, my brain doesn't really gel with FM synthesis. But it's an extremely powerful technique. I'm in awe of Autechre and their usage. If you really dig FM there's an *amazing* book that John Chowing wrote in the 80s for the Yamaha DX7 which is the best thing I've ever read on FM. It's goes for $500 today, but you can find a .pdf for free no problem. Strong recommend if you want to build up your intuitions for FM.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Lastly, don't worry yourself at this point with settings like diffusion, early reflections, and modulation. They all have a purpose, but they're usually more subtle than you should be worrying about at this point.

The big parameters to master are verb length, pre-delay time, and dry/wet balance, with some filtering. Those are going to do 90% of the heavy lifting for you, along with your choice of algorithm (hall, plate, room, spring, etc).

author: Deleted User
content:
the controller is called continuum. I believe it is an mpe (midi polyphonic expressions) device. I don’t know much about kyma but i would look into physical modeling because this is what the sound generation is based on. A lot of physical modeling is heavily based on delay lines, so I’d start there. Modal synthesis is also another cool concept where you would feed an impulse sample into a bank of parallel bandpass filters (very narrow q- which is also constructed with delay lines fundamentally). The idea is feedback and resonance from the filters would emulate acoustic modes. 

You can emulate this with fairly cheap stuff like leap motion, I’ve done a different project (something much simpler) with leap motion for gesture controlled music concrète. But you can definitely use the gestures to do the same thing with physical modeling. I’d be down to work on something together if you’re interested!

author: delwin
content: yeah I don’t care so much about the gestures or performance of it — mostly just how the sounds are generated. I’ve done delay-line based synthesis in max/msp and reaktor but can’t find much info at all on what kyma calls “slipstick” synthesis (distinguishing it from karplus-strong), which is supposed to model friction-induced sounds, rather than impact-induced sounds.

author: delwin
content:
I do this a lot!

In Ableton, you have soooo many options. Most often I put the sample on an Ableton Simpler and am able to slice / pitch / etc really fluidly — record that, and then edit by hand. This is my workflow for 90% of vocal chops. If it’s really simple I’ll do it by hand but I find I get more musical results if I can “play” the chop. 

There’s also Buffer Shuffler and Beat Repeat in Ableton which can be fun and unpredictable. 

The Glitch Machines plugins are also really nice if you’re going for something a bit crazy (two of them are free and very good). I don’t fully understand them yet so I just throw them on when I want something wacky to happen. 

And I’ll also second stutter edit — very fun for “playing” chops live too, and editing presets isn’t too hard either.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
yeah its very case by case. as far as groove in relation to other elements. I've had guitars recorded loosely toa click and worked the groove around that - lining up the downbeats of the drums/bass  with the guitars even if it's a bit early or late. that was for a more indie type of joint. and for something more trap /modern hip hop, I've nudged bass notes or samples to get them to either sync w drums up for impact  or nudge slightly off to hype of of pull back the energy in the groove. 

as far as programming. I'll play with forward swing and dragging notes a lot if I'm going for a more real/dynamic feel when programming. keeping in mind that if the goal is trying to stay "on time" any fwd swing that might happen at the start of a phrase will be compensated with some drag  after or vice versa.  keeping velocities in mind w drum hits + linking it to a filter env so that harder hits have more high end and softer hits end up a bit rounder.

adding subtle layers that are similar   to the main drums but occupy a different texture or tone  in dif  sections to thicken up the groove or automate the attack /sustain of certain elements thru diff sections to help shift the listener  focus throughout

author: Slow Hand
content:
Ahhh gotcha. That's a cool goal.

So it sounds like part of what you're seeking are techniques to add pitched resonance to samples that may be atonal?

Well a resonator is a great start. If you're not already into it, I'd look into the karplus-strong theorem and physical modeling synthesis. That whole field has a lot of overlap with what you're describing. It's the kind of thing you'd hear Sophie or Jimmy Edgar do with their Elektron Monomachine.

*AAS* have a whole suite of physical modeling products that function similar to *resonator*, but are third-party plugins. Doing percussion synthesis with *Chromaphone* can do a pretty convincing recreation of certain percussion tones with the added bonus of being as flexible as a synthesizer, because it is a synthesizer!

You could tune a high-feedback delay unit until it rings at the pitch you're seeking. I can elaborate if you need more explanation. Funnily, that's the entire basis for physical modeling synthesizers.

Alternately, you could layer your samples with gently-blended sine tones. That's worth a try too. I know a lot of EDM producers are into this.

author: Slow Hand
content:
It's really simple. It's basically creating a loop within a sampler and reducing the loop length to such a small window of time that the looped audio is perceived as a pitch. You "tune" it by adjusting the loop length shorter or longer.

I think the biggest issue is that vanilla samplers don't tend to give you very fine control unless they're built for sound design. Their loop length parameter will often go from 5 ms - 5000 ms, when what you really need is a loop in the 1 ms - 100 ms range.

So it might involve a custom-built device in *Reaktor* or something equivalent.

author: Deleted User
content:
All of these methods suggested will yield in different results. 

Resonators are made from delay using feedback to create tones. So you may need to resample to kill sustains - or not if you want it to have lengthiness. If you are going for SOPHIE kind of sound then you'd probably keep the feedback. 

Booms (filter resonance) are similar mechanisms but less tonal unless you turn up the feedback a lot more - it will certainly be more natural sounding as opposed to comb-filtery sound. 

Layering will give more focused pitch while maintaining the integrity of the layered sample sound, you would probably have the most control this way. 

Vocoder will have inherently baked sound because of the synthesis mechanism, it can be desirable or not depending on the scenario. 

With sampler looping, you will get grainier tail - dialing in the decay is necessary if you want the sound to be percussive because it will just continue sustaining. You can create pads this way too!

author: austenballard
content: So this is the kick drum: I've set the frequency to the root note of the key the song is in (in this case C), low feedback so that it just adds a *hint* of tone, low pass filter, and then I'm using the envelope to control the dry/wet so the attack of the unfiltered sample happens before the tone comes in to avoid messing with the transient - these are for drums, after all

author: Slow Hand
content:
Totally. 

So I should clarify a little bit. These 3-4 patches aren't static sounds that I never change. Think of them more like initialized synth templates with pre-determined routings and modulation that I can start with and then diverge from. I still use other people's presets, but using these templates can save me a good 15 minutes every time that I want to build a new patch and don't want to start all the way from scratch. They come with a lot of built-in expression.

On most of these I've got a lot of the keyboard tracking already tuned so that a bright patch doesn't get too harsh as I go up in register or it doesn't get too flabby and lose definition in the low-end.

I've got one patch set up for very expressive pitch modulation. Lots of big sweeps and bends in the attack/release envelope phases. Think wonky Neptunes-type sounds or two-octave dive bombs. Stuff like that.

One patch is set for expressive filter and amplitude modulation. Wobbles, envelope modulations, and such. It's my go-to if I'm trying to play with some "brassy" dynamics.

One is a legato mono patch for very fluid vocal-like playing. A big emphasis on note articulation and variation. I think of it as a solo instrument.

The final one is (you called it) A nice poly synth. Think James Blake on a Prophet. Pretty standard stuff, but once again it's got keyboard tracking that's tuned up so that the patch feels rich across the entire range.

author: Slow Hand
content: I'm really not much of a template guy. I love building everything from scratch, whether it's instrument patches, DAW setups, or effects chains. But these synth settings are hard-won and I spend so much time repeating them that I finally saved them. 😄

author: Ross Fortune
content:
From a cursory Synthtopia scan:

"So it seems that Luis Fernando Zepeda is part of the Organist generation of 60s-70s Mexico City with others like Evaristo Enriquez or Juan Torres.
This technique was “invented” by Tito Enriquez but perfected by Ernesto “Hill” Gil Olvera, whom was blind, and recorded LPs under the advertising that he played “the Organ that Talks!”

I found on a random blog that the drawbar configuration was something like this, you started with:
A = 88 8000 000 00
E = 80 8080 000 00
I = 80 0080 000 00
O = 80 8000 000 00
U = 80 0000 000 00

And you worked them with your left hand as you played with your right hand and play bass with with left foot and expression with right foot. It is a Hammond X66"


There's lots of Ernesto Gil Olvera stuff on YT, but I (and my nephew) don't like it is as much as this Luis Fernando Zepeda track. Can't find anything else by him unfortunately.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Hmmm. I wouldn't say that you *need* a Moog, but they're always a nice color to have in the kit. And it doesn't hurt that they're a "classic" sound, so having one around wouldn't be a bad investment and will likely see a lot of use over the years.

The last generation of Moog synths (from Sub37 onward) have been very gritty and have a lot of options for drive and feedback, which allows them to get very rough, in contrast to the Dave Smith synths which tend to be cleaner, buzzy, and articulate. These days Moogs are very warm, thick, and gritty. They're extremely easy on the ears, even when you're cranking the drive. The core components of Moog sound *really* good and there's a lot of care that's gone into the raw sound of these things. Namely the oscillators and the filter circuit. They are *very* well designed instruments. In fact, I'd say that they're *beautiful* instruments.

My recommendation for someone who's not super-deep into synthesis but wants to own a Moog would be to buy a *Subsequent 37*. It's got digitally recallable presets, whereas *Matriarch* and *Grandmother* are semi-modular and have little/no preset capability. The Subsequent 37 is plug and play, has a great set of unique features, wonderful grit, and is very fun to play.

Keep in mind that the *Subsequent 37* is a monophonic synth. Technically it's paraphonic (can play up to *two* notes at a time), but you're not going to be playing any chords on it like on your Prophet.

author: Slow Hand
content: Hmmm. Fun sound. My guess is that it's probably not a ring mod (though it sounds similar) because the modulation ratio is tracking with each note. It's likely some sort of heavy modulation (ala FM synthesis). Something like amplitude modulation, or phase modulation. Unfortunately I don't have time to run it down for you.

author: Deleted User
content:
@RÜSSO Here a serum patch. It's close enough - but if you want it to be exactly the same then you'll likely have to find out what synth they used. You could try tweaking the waveform to a slightly different Saw wave, but this is probably as close you'll get with the Serum LPFs and enveloping. You'll need to mess around with pitch bend and attack time to get the performative aspect of this lead line, and especially when you do the pitch bend - you might need some help from the compressor to get the sustain out of that slow pitch bend,

Whenever you hear buzziness it's usually LFO on OSC level on a faster rate. This same lead sound is all over different styles of EDM so it's a good patch to know. Kaskade - Atmosphere has the same lead but in square wave with other layers as well.

author: Josh
content: Does anyone have a preference on where I can learn about FM synthesis? I’m big dumb so trying to figure this out cold turkey is driving me insane.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Ok. So the book *FM Theory and Applications* by John Chowning is the one to get. John Chowing "invented" FM synthesis and wrote *the* damn the book on it. I read it a decade ago when I had access to a world class music library and it was the single best resource I've found on the topic. And I've read a lot of them.

Chowning demonstrates patches by building them up unit by unit using the Yamaha DX7, but the techniques are platform agnostic and any FM synth worth it's salt will do what you need to follow along.

The book is a collector's item these days and sells for $500-$1000/copy, but you can find a .pdf scan online. I'd print it out and go through the examples. DM me if you have trouble finding it.

Also, if anyone ever wants to buy me a gift, this would be a safe bet.
https://www.amazon.com/Fm-Theory-Applications-Musicians/dp/4636174828

author: Slow Hand
content:
Does anyone know if there's a program, synth, or protocol that allows you to modulate synthesizer envelope times based on the duration of the MIDI note?

For example, if I draw a quarter note (on the piano roll) and my synth plays a one octave downward sweep it would take a quarter note's worth of time to execute that sweep. But if I draw a MIDI note with a whole-note duration the synthesizer would modulate it's envelope time and that same sweep would descend over the course of a whole-note.

The synth would have to read upcoming MIDI note lengths from the the piano roll and modulate it's parameters on a note by note basis by reading the note duration before the note-on message. There would have to be some sort of communication between the synth and the DAW, and of course it would not work in real time.

author: Slow Hand
content: Yeah. It certainly seems doable, but I think someone would have to design a protocol for soft synths and DAWs to talk to each other in this way. It would be huge, though.

author: Slow Hand
content: It would be cool if there was an ARA-like integration where the synthesizer's sequencer could exist in place of the piano roll.

content: Doing it manually is probably the safest bet until someone writes a Max patch to automate it. Print to audio, slice at the note start and end, and then hit *R* to reverse the desired notes.

author: Slow Hand
content:
You may already be aware, but you can get very different textures by playing with the LFO shape on the tremolo. 

The bass is more of a sine/triangle shape while those vocal samples have harder edges, closer to a square wave. The square wave modulating volume at high rates will give you that "ripple" I think you may be hearing.

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content: Dumb question time: Is there a trick to getting a consistent distorted power chord guitar tone with mixed in non-5th intervals? Like going from a C to a C/E (which will have a minor 6th in the bottom E+C) the intermodulation and breakup sounds entirely different with all settings I’ve tried. How would you approach it to make sure it sits similarly?

author: LAPhill
content: Couldn't you do this on a synth that's one oscillator per voice? If you're consistent about the amount of notes in a chord, it'd be pretty easy to try and see how it sounds.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Synths could easily do this, but they’re rarely designed in a way that would give you different oscillator timbres per note. 

They’ll give you copies of the same oscillator setting for each note, but they don’t change the timbre based on which note is being played in a chord.

author: Will Pragnell
content: Also, some software synths (e.g. Serum) definitely allow you to use the note being played as a modulation source for arbitrary parameters, though that would be a bit clumsy for this example

Yeah. It is... overwhelming the first time you open it. Making sense of it takes time. I'm still hacking away at parts of it. The sequencer alone is a beast.

Of course, it's like that for all but the simplest synthesizers. Even if you've got the fundamentals of synthesis down cold and know exactly what you want to do, every single synth has a learning curve as you get used to it's flow and idiosyncrasies.

That's the reason that I committed to it as a single synth. The cost of switching from one synth to another was too taxing. Each synth really is it's own instrument.

author: Zack Hames
content:
So, I think it’s superbly underrated. Especially the new Akai MPC lives, one, etc series.

I use it as a drum machine/sampler/sequencer for all of my hardware synths. It’s the brain and controller for everything.

But you can also use it completely on its own, you can put any sample all the way across a keyboard/pads to the correct pitch automatically. 

There are built in AIR effects. You can time stretch, etc do whatever with samples. 

Load up any drum samples and go to town. 

It also has some built in instruments / synths, but I rarely use those. 

It’s essentially a portable DAW as far as music production. I prefer it to computer by far for producing / writing with samples and synths

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
My current approach to this involves a couple of principles, but this is the first that comes to mind:

1. If there’s a part with bg vocals performing different lines than the lead and there’s a lot going on, I try to have a spot earlier in the song where the exactly lines those BGs are performing have a moment to shine. For example, if there’s a low energy bridge where they can be clearly understood before the big hook where they can be perceived but not understood as well in the midst of so much. 

What this does is allow the listeners brain to process what’s being said with little effort, and then later when it’s in a tornado they can still perceive what it’s saying because they recognize it as something their brain already knows, so it’s not overwhelming for their brain to understand the words of multiple vocals going at once if there are layers of lines being performed (usually syncopated) around each other.

This applies to instruments as well, but instead of intelligibility of words I focus more on cutting frequencies so everything can fit well in the big moments. If they head a synth at full power in the intro and it comes back for a final hook, you can get away with cutting a lot of meat off of it and still have it be perceived as the same synth, without muddying the mix and also creating a nice ‘bringing the song full circle’ feeling - If the track calls for that.

I typed this off the cuff based in gut instinct so not standing by this message as full proof, but this all feels right to me as I explore what I have done for tracks, without having this much thought or words to it.

But had it widen to over 80% in chorus. Then more narrow than I would normally have a doubled melodic at like 35%. Usually id just do one guitar, mono to scratch the scene change itch. author: Zack Hames
content:
here's the workflow:

I don't use many of the preset kits anymore. Just not really the sounds I'm looking for. I have a massive library of samples that i like to use. Accessing those is easy.
The problem is I don't make preset kits. Every session, every kit, is a different combination of things, always starting fresh. So I am in the Library view constantly going through samples/files to load into any Cell of Battery.

When I find a sound I like, I can click it or drag it to the cell I want. This is all great.

But, the second i drop it in, I have to change the velocity from 0-100% (I saved my default preset to have all cells at 0% velocity which seems to be working). and then *every time i add a new sample or replace a sample* it makes it a loop in the "Editor" window. There is no shortcut, no preference, no saving a preset, that allows me to essentially remove that behavior.

author: longstoryshort
content:
one of my earlier experiences writing for other people (ghost producing for a few DJs) in that same kinda lane, future bass ish

i used to produce before i would *write* sometimes, and the energy would just get sucked right out of the room

as soon i opened serum they'd say oh we're not getting a record done today

that moment really hurt me at that time, but later on i realized it was true - it's always the true criticism that really hits, right?

so i made adjustments by building out my sounds/library/synth patches in advance, so when sessions came up i would be able to just fire in 90% of the way done sounds.

when the song was written then i'd finish up the sounds and do the tweaking and the session had so much momentum it didn't take long to finish.

records got done, money was made, everyone was happier.

author: Akanksha
content:
you're so right
sometimes we fail to understand the difference between creative exploration and being stuck in the process of creation.

I also have let go of my habit of watching endless tutorials before starting a session. I especially dislike going down the rabbit hole of  those "50 advanced production tricks to level up your sound" videos. It's like why am I watching this instead of creating some actual music first?

yes, creating a bank of samples and sounds beforehand is the way to go. 
On those days, I'll just spend my time doing sound design and exploring sounds that fit the genre. 

I've realised that scheduling and managing time well is important, even in music.

Btw, did you talk about the vibe and atmosphere of the track in advance with your clients in order to do better sound selection for the style they wanted to go for?

author: Slow Hand
content:
Are you looking for truly anechoic samples? Or just the sensation of anechoic samples?

Have you tried asking an audio AI to resynthesize the audio file with no room reflections? I'd be curious to know how well it can do that. If at all. Or a de-verb algorithm.

As for drying out a sound, you can get pretty far with a few tools (or a combination of them):
1. Turn down the sustain knob on a transient designer.
2. An algorithm that replicates Ableton's *beats* warp mode. (slicing a file at each transient and applying a fade out on each slice.
3. Gentle de-verbing in RX.

author: austenballard
content:
I also really like to get hyper-organized inside the project folders so I make a folder for bounces, a folder for committed trackouts (which i prefer vs freeze/flatten, but do it however it works for you), and then folders for ancillary stuff like lead sheets, lyric sheets, etc

also make sure you each bounce after each version

also helps to freeze (but not flatten) in case your collaborator doesn't have the same plugins or presets or whatever so you can keep rolling back and forth even if you're using different plugins
